summary: God's love for the world is expressed through the gift of his only Son, so that belief in him leads to eternal life rather than perishing.
The Son was sent not to condemn the world but to save it, and belief or unbelief in him determines a person's standing before God.
The passage uses light and darkness as metaphors: those who do evil avoid the light, while those who live by truth come to the light willingly.

named_entities.name: God
named_entities.description: The one who loved the world and gave his only begotten Son

named_entities.name: the Son
named_entities.description: Sent into the world not to judge but to save

questions.text: According to verse 16, what is God's stated motivation for giving his only begotten Son?
What does verse 18 say determines whether a person is judged or not?
How does the contrast between light and darkness in verses 19-21 describe the human condition as the passage presents it?
What does it mean, in terms of the passage's own language, to 'come to the light'?
Based on verse 17's statement that the Son was sent to save rather than condemn, how might this shape the way you speak about faith with others?
